column11: Review Text

This is a little piece of heaven located beside a mad bus station. It is a simply stunning park , very carefully laid out . It is maintained and manicured to a very high level. There are a multitude of flowers, shrubs, plants and trees in this park. There are lots of areas to sit in the shade and watch the world pass by. There is also a little cafe located within the park. 1000 rupees entry fee for foreigners ‚Ä¶ well worth it.

A nice place to visit in Nuwara Eliya. Our favourite was the rose garden within the park A nice small cafeteria inside that serves delicious masala tea as well, especially when its quite cold this gives a nice warm up.

Relaxing and caring, it is like an immense garden, as everything is perfectly drawn.with streams crossing it and some emblematic tree. It's wide. Some more remote area is not clean. It's part of the itinerary if you're walking around town.

Very nice park in the middle of a dirty and noisy environment. The park costs 1000 rupees admission and is worth visiting. Where just a few meters away is a busy bus station the park welcomes you with peace and beauty. The park is not huge but you can stay here for at least 1 hour and enjoy the well-kept grounds. Unfortunately, Sri Lanka has a big garbage problem. There's tons of plastic waste everywhere. Therefore it is nice to see such a well-kept complex for a change
Really well-kept park and garden, very much like we used to have in the U.K. before we ran out of money, plenty of nice places to sit and watch the world go by.

It is worth the 1000 rupee entry. The walk is relaxing and the amount of care that goes into creating and maintaining this park is outstanding. Do relax and enjoy the stroll where you will see trees that you‚Äôve never seen before.

column8: Great stroll round beautifully tended park
column11: Beautiful British style park . Amazingly well tended with beautiful flowers and trees . There is a cafe in the park . Cost 1000sl rupees to get in . Don‚Äôt miss quick stroll round the small museum which features old photographs of nuwara eliya

column8: Small park in the heart of Nuwara Eliya
column11: Small park in the heart of the town. Clean lawns and well maintained plants. There wasn‚Äôt much variety though. We were impressed by the massive Gum trees - haven‚Äôt seen them this big even in Oz. The park is a quiet place to relax after a morning out hiking.
Big beautiful and relaxing but prices are bit high for tourists . It is otherwise located in city centre of Nuwara Eliya.
Foreigners pay an entrance fee of Rs. 600, but the site is quite large and it is a very nice environment to take a leisurely walk while enjoying tropical flowers.
It's just like any well maintained good park but nothing much to differentiate it. Good for morning or evening walks. Green with lots of flowers

Victoria park is a public park located in Nuwaraeliya. Next to the nuwaraeliya post office in srilanka üá±üá∞.originally the park was the research field of hakgala botanical garden.the park was formerly named in 1897 to commemorate the Diamond jubilee of Queen Victoria.

As non-residents of Sri Lanka, we paid 500 Sri Lankan rupees each to enter the park. It was a Sunday in August and there were many visitors in the park. We saw some beautiful old trees and gorgeous flowers. The park was generally very well maintained. Worth a trip if you fancy a walk around somewhere peaceful.

Victoria Park in nuwara eliya is a beautiful park with some very old and large trees. Very peaceful, clean and non-commercial. There is also a small canteen in the park. One can visit the same if you have spare time in nuwara eliya.

What an amazing park! Highly recommended our 4 year old loved it . Beuatiful flowers impressive trees and quiet a few wild birds. super clean and great play area for kids well worth the 500 rupees entrance.  Happy families and kids running around a park that European cities would envy

A public park that charges 500 lkr per person Thats itself is a joke On a different note, maintained decent enough and has a good children play area but nothing thats exceptional or something that makes it a must go place when in Nuwara Skip it is what I would suggest

Excellent "English style" park, which is not a shock given the area's past ! Needs a map maybe and few extra seats. I don't object to paying an admission charge, but having different (and much higher) rates for foreigners is totally wrong (and doesn't encourage tourists, who are vital to the ailing Sri Lankan economy).
It‚Äôs a great old park with some lovely old trees and plenty of flowers in the spring but not in February. Small museum of photos once inside near the entrance worth a wander

It‚Äôs like any other city park. We visited it in Jan, probably not the best month to visit as they were preparing the flower beds, and it was muddy at a few places. Also rainy day is not the best time to visit a park.  It is lush green and I am sure Feb or March would be the best season when flowers bloom.

A bit disappointed not to get a map on entry (as entry is expensive for foreigners who probably need and should get a map). But once in you could sense the pride and ownership of the park keepers in preparing this place for the next blooming season. Only wish I could come back to see it. Also sorry to see that the cafe was closed - would have been so nice to sit and admire the park with a drink in hand
The park is beautiful and clean with variety of trees and flowers . the kids will enjoy playing there. you can relax and take a plenty of photos.
A decent park, with a very nice mesuem which we nearly missed, make sure you pass by it. We were living at the westbury palace which is 5 minutes away we we thought we should pass by it.

A very well maintained garden, so lovely to explore. We spent about 2 hours in there! There are lots of beautiful flowers to look at and photo opportunities. Special thank you to gardener Tony for showing us some flowers we hadn't spotted - very kind man.
Cost 500 rupees to enter per foreign adult. Have to pay to use toilet. Came here to kill time before the train. Had a nice selection of flowers. Greenhouse was locked with succulents inside.
I spent about an hr here , cost 500 rupees, I would consider it a botanical garden not just a park. Theres a greenhouse as well but was locked, all the flowers are well kept. I enjoyed.

This is the first time in my life that I paid an entrance fee to get to a park. Not that much, but it's there. As everywhere at Sri Lanka, foreigners have different rates than locals. The park is interesting, I would say, reminds me somehow Great Britain. The trees and plants are taken good care of. You can find also some statues at the place. Some of them are nice, some of them are straightforward kitsch. There are also toilets at the park, but at the time that I visited the park, the particular toilet building that I was passing was not working at the time, so you can't totally count with that.
This is a large, beautiful park with many different flower varieties.  There is a small museum showing the history of the area with a wonderful lady telling us about it all.   Would recommend.
Victoria Park is an elegantly landscaped garden filled with lovely blooms. There is a kids play area for children. It is a nice place for bird watching too.

The initial surprise here was paying 400 rupees per person to enter. I don't think I've encountered a city or town park in the UK or Europe you pay to enter. But it is only ¬£1.40 and the park is very nice. Small, only 800 metres if you enter through one gate and go straight to exit the other but with other paths within the park and pretty arrays of flowers, shrubs and trees it is a quiet respite from the busy town.

It has a children park. Avoid weekends and holidays since it may be crowded. But even if this place is crowded you can enjoy it very much. Better try to allocate 2-3 hours and cover all. There is a museum too. But unfortunately it was closed both time I went there in 2018 and 2022.

I arrived at the eastern gate at 7.10 am.  The park is supposed to be open at 7 am. There was no one at the ticket window. The security man said come back at 7.30. I said ‚Äú but it should be open now‚Äù. He then demanded to see my ID! Whatever for? I left and went to the main gate, which was open. The entrance fee for foreigners is 400lkr! I have an interest in birds so walked slowly around the park. I didn‚Äôt see many birds‚Ä¶.. but piles of rubbish and litter everywhere!
Good to spend time when you have free time away from other attractions. Need to pay entrance fee. Good environment. Need to focus on cleaning up trash filled  stream.
we visited this park in the evening and it was really interesting had a hand full of flowers, but needs maintenance
Well maintained.  Getting ready for the April season. Enjoyed with the family. Worth the time spent. will visit again.

Well maintained.  The Council has invested in the park in recent years.  Ideal for an informal picnic.  Mature trees,  attractive bedding. Bird watchers know it as a place for fairly rare species.  If birds are your interest visit in the evening.

The park is very well maintained kudos to the concerned authority. There is an area for kids and it is  just an ideal place for a morning or evening walk. If you need a quiet green oasis to relax in the city of Nuwara Eliya, this is just the idyllic location.
we visited here on our trip to nuwareliya. Beautiful place, with various types of flowers and different pathways and layouts. Would have been better if the canteen was in better quality.

It‚Äôs a Real Paradise for Kids! A pleasant place to go, especially if you have a small child who‚Äôs happy with a play area and doesn‚Äôt expect anything very sophisticated. All children below 12 years of age must be accompanied by an adult. This is a pretty large park, full of trees, flowerbeds, even topiary‚Äîbushes shaped into elephants, rabbits, and other creatures. There are several spaces with outdoor play structures, from slides and swings to see-saws and monkey bars. Some spaces are specially designed for younger children (with smaller slides, shorter ladders) and some for older children. Specially the Train ride is great for the kids as well as the adults! The location is heart of the town. My wife, daughter and I spent about two hours at the park. There is a very small fee to enjoy the park. Parking is available on the side streets. The scenery is beautiful and it is the perfect location for photographs. I truly recommend this park for children and as well as for adults.
Well maintained gardens.  Pleasant to walk around. Good to see so many locals enjoying this facility.  Good variety of lovely flowers
Victoria Park is a small but well laid out botanical park that is home to a large number of flora. Good place for photographs.
Would have been superb if a coffee shop we anywhere nearby. But yes... Very pleasant with a large collection of Australian gum trees and lovely flower garden beds
Perfect for evening relaxation and long walks along with people who are really close to you. Not much crowd. There are places for kids to play and couples to sit and have an romantic evening.

Victoria Park, Nuwara Eliya First thing to note, although this is common, foreigners (you) get charged 300 rupees to enter. Locals are free. We paid our fee to the lady behind the counter. As I turned around a male guard asked to check my ticket. He‚Äôd just seen me buy it but never mind. We saw signs stating no plastic bottles or bags were allowed as they become litter. The place was filthy with litter of all types but mostly plastic bottles. In one of the free flowing water areas there were several old tyres which had clearly been there for ages.  It was obvious the bottles were not all from the day before due to the condition or grubbiness  of them. We picked some up and gave them to one of the many guards and staff but there was too much for us to manage. No one appeared to be proactively litter picking when our perception was that a person could have been tasked with this. There was clearly ongoing work judging by the piles of garden debris but again our perception, this appeared to an effort to tidy the place up when it had been neglected over time. We noticed some of the plants were covered in graffiti scratched into their leaves. Some people eh! But then we saw what appeared to be locals rather than foreigners doing exactly that. Despite the wealth of staff and uniformed guards this behaviour was unchallenged so we did, loudly. These plants surrounded a water feature which was not in operation. There was a wooden jetty into the feature which looked 20 years past its prime, basically derelict and in need of removal. I know this is not main season so the gardens would not be at their best but the overall impression was of poor and overdue management. Overall we were disappointed and would not recommend this unless you have nothing else to do. So we left and walked up to the nearby lake which was even worse! Again we were asked to buy a ticket, from where we were we could see rubbish floating everywhere.  Don‚Äôt bother unless you want to see a few horses tethered. Nuwara Eliya is grossly overrated and was a shame to waste two booked nights there.

We had a lovely couple of hours walked around Victoria Park - a bit of a haven of peace and quiet from the hustle and bustle of traffic etc. with plenty of shady seating (and clean and well maintained western toilets!) The park is well laid out and maintained with areas set aside for specific plant/tree species. We're not flora or tree experts so didn't bother taking a guided tour just used the informative map you get with your ticket. A lovely way to spend a few hours.

A large expansive park in the heart of Nuwara Eliya, with extensive lawns, flower bed and a large cascading pond. A great place to relax and spend an afternoon. While i didn't visit the park at its most colourful ( Apparently this is April/ May time when all the bedding plants are in full bloom) At the point of my visit these were still being planted up.....however there's still much to see and admire. Also good for the soul.

Botanical Garden - Since this is located a few miles out of town, it does not attract a large number of visitors like Gregory Lake, Victoria Park etc.  However, it is a beautiful park with old trees, a nice Japanese and other landscaped gardens.  Well worth a visit to have a walk in the midst of these trees and fresh air. A brief word on the other park/lake with which Nuwara Eliya is blessed.  Gregory lake is beautiful, but getting to be overcrowded, particularly the entrance where there are pony rides, roadside vendors and car park ‚Äì all rolled into one.

Visited here in Jan/20, likely a couple of months before the park would be seen in its best light. It was not unexpectedly named in 1897 to commemorate the diamond jubilee of Queen Victoria. One of the gardeners gave us a tour for the better part of a half hour, clearly loving to show off the park. The birders are not forgotten nor the ophiophilists. The backside of a cobra was seen, resting among dead leaves! It is a nice spot to chill. There is a kiddies' area. The entry fee for foreigners was 300 rupees.

Very disappointing. Out of season for flowers (Feb) - I understand that, but the river in particular was full of trash and A DEAD CAT! Seriously, this is supposed to be a well manicured garden. Awful!

I was not very impressed with this garden. it had pretty much the same flora and fauna as in the Botanical gardens. What I was taken aback was the number of birds in this place. Certainly worth if you are into bird watching

Located in the centre of the city, this one is a lovely park to spend some in Nuwara eliya. The entry tickets are around 200 LKR which are justified. The park has a lot of green spaces which are very well maintained. There are some rides for small kids which they would enjoy. They also have a kids train which runs within the park. The park is very well maintained. Though not a major tourist attraction, the park can surely be visited.

Took the children to play before a long trip on the train. They loved running and climbing. The miniature train  ride was fun and was 50lkr   We spent about an hour here but you could bring a picnic and explore the rest of the beautiful gardens. Toilets are in the main park are very clean

This is quite a nice park but not a 'must do'. Just make sure you pay for entry - the ticket counter is tucked away behind the gate we came through and it's not well signed to say you have to pay. We walked through on our exploration of Nuwara Eliya and it was a nice respite from the busy streets.

Nice park for a stroll - foreigners need to pay 300 to enter. The walk is very short though, so i didnt think it was worth the money. It took us about 20 mins to complete one round. I wouldnt visit again - try the botanical gardens in Kandy, that is worth it!
Beautiful park and location, several local plants and fauna. Great place to spend the day or even for a picnic.

Victoria Park in Nuwara Eliya is a Nice Park to visit and have a little walk with the family. They have a children corner with a good number of games. Good to visit if have plenty of time in the city.
Very nice spot to spend an hour or so! There is a children‚Äôs park which is quite big but a bit knackered, still quite pleasant (if spoilt by the surly guards).
Great place with lot of plants and visit during morning time. Near to  market and restaurants. Good for take pictures.

This park is a nicely laid out English style garden. When we visited many of the areas in the park were being renovated and so the floral displays were not fantastic. The Public Toilets within the park were dreadful and not really fit to use, which was very disappointing. It‚Äôs worth the visit, but considerable improvement is warranted from Park Management.
It's a nice park were you can see many different exotic plants and trees. If you have time it's worth a visit.

Lovely park. There is a small entrance fee. Plan to spend about 30 minutes strolling around at a leisurly pace. There's also a kids park, which we didn't visit. The Tudor-style Nuwara Eliya post office, built in 1894, is across the street from one of the exits, so you can kill two birds with one stone.
Better place for children play, it's good place to visit for family, nuwaraeliya have 2 gardens this is little small but middle of city nice place

Nice place to chill among trees, flowers and lawns. Quite and peaceful place. We were pleasantly surprised by a chief gardener who offered us to guide through the park and show all the remarkable plants and flowers. That was nice and amazing. My best regards

As with Gregory lake and contrary to other reviews Victoria park is NOT free, with tickets costing 250 rupees per adult. The park itself is immaculately maintained and has some wonderful photogenic features and native flora. If you walk around the to the rear of the school there is a children's  playground which looked reasonably exciting for the young ones. Worth the entry cost.
This was in our plan and a very beautiful park with a number of variety of flowers.  The park is well maintained.
a beautiful landscaping and a great place to sit and spend the early evening hours. We had a good time.

Hi, This the wonderland in Sril Lanka middle of the hill country.Its 158 Km far from Colombo Airport and take near 5 hours direct driving. This is  real beautiful park and easy traveling inside with fantastic romantic feeling. Many more activity near their and star class hotels,eco hotels,bungalows, food stalls any time available.Lots of flowers can see in this park and its have tall fee to entering. Thanks.

A beautiful place for picnics or just spending the day. A lot of people come here on the weekends. There are lots of activities such as jet ski rides,  paddle boats or speed boats. Scenery is just stunning . Centrally located and well worth a visit or a picnic with the family.  Plenty of parking areas and long foot paths for walking.
Simply amazing ‚ù§Ô∏è it was so beautifully arranged and greener. Really enjoyed. Just like a little England !!
This park gives a compact view of beauty of the Nuwara Eliya area. Very nice and beautiful setting especially during the April - May season.

We had a lovely walk around the gardens. One of the gardeners took us around for awhile until he realised we were happy to amble on our own. It‚Äôs well laid out although there was way too much litter around. Very interesting selection of plants. The little museum in the grounds was well worth popping into.
Very well maintained park. If you staying in the city, it is within walking distance. Good place to take a stroll.
An easy stroll in the park. Flowers were blooming, weather was so cool and nice- a simple park which was easy to walk in and get closer to nature in an easy way!
Just in the middle of the city, well maintained clean and green. In a Victorian design. If you have some free time to spend.
A pleasant place to wander around, in the nice fresh temperatures of Nuwara Eliya. We weren't that impressed with the town overall, but this, along with a couple of the hotels, was the highlight.
That is a amazing place in the nuwaraeliya city with very beautiful gardening styles.i love there floral beuties and also very beautiful nature.
Pay a small entry fee. Lovely space for the children to enjoy and the gardens are well maintained. A highlight in Nuwara Eliya.

Nurses Elita is a place for families of Sri Lanka to gather. The park is no exception. Lovely to see so many families enjoying the beautiful grounds.  Some spectacular trees including a flowering bouganvillia arch.  A little expensive for tourists but still a worthwhile place to spend a few hours.

It is one of the must go places if you are in Nuwara Eliya. I have been going to this park ever since I was a kid but I must say it still looks the same. There's so much room for improvement and I do hope that someone will look into this treasure and give the needed attention. This place can attract thousands for sure with the beautiful gardens and the nice flowers. I went to a washroom which was super unclean and not upto the expected level. When i was there it started raining and then only saw how ugly the surrounding was. There was this small canal and it was so dirty too. It is a natural park and definitely a tourist attraction and I hope things will be better soon,
This park is located right in the center of Nuwara Eliya and also right in front of the city post office. Nice place but haven't looked after well.
Lovely peaceful gardens, lawn and flowers worth a visit , we enjoyed relaxing after a big hike . Stop after for a refreshing cup of tea with local products.

I visited this delightful park on a sunny afternoon with the main aim of birdwatching  . The park was buzzing with families , couples and groups of schoolchildren enjoying themselves . The planted beds were attractive and a few neglected areas were being worked on . My main focus was along a stream inside the park boundary where I had close views of a variety of birds including two scarce Himalayan migrants ; Pied Ground Thrush and Kashmiri Flycatcher .

This was the only place in Sri Lanka which disappointed us. It should be lovely but it seems neglected and in a poor state. It is apparently under renovation but is not worth visiting at present. I even heard of someone who demanded a refund because they were so disappointed.

We visited Victoria Park twice during our time in Nuwara Eliya. The first time to just explore and the second time for a nature walk organised through the hotel. There is an entrace fee for the park, which would be fine if the park was actually maintained with the fee. We were incredibly dismayed by the sheer amount of litter in the park. Surely someone or a community group could organise some clean ups (if I had had a spare bag and gloves during our visit I would have happily removed some of the plastic waste myself). Rubbish aside, the park is a pleasant place to spend some time. There were plenty of flowers out when we visited (albeit the same as the ones we frequently see in the UK) and different areas to explore. Many local children come to play games as well as couples and larger families just enjoying the surrounds. From a nature perspective there were a few bird species and squirrels but not the rich levels elsewhere in Sri Lanka.
garden with flowers,nice landscapes,and lovely for couples,we visited the place in the evening time,very nice place in Nuwara Eliya

This was a nice and peaceful place to take  stroll but since it was under so much renovation, it was difficult to really get a full sense of it. It looked as if they had done a lot of projects in the past, but failed to maintain them while starting on further new projects. So it was a bit of a shame as it could have done with some TLC.

A beautiful green space located in the very busy town of Nuwara Eliya, it was so nice to walk/stroll around amongst the greenery, we loved ‚Äúlittle england‚Äù as it is known, for its colonial settlement
Well maintained park in the heart of Nuwara Eliya. You will be able see different types of flowers. Really beautiful.

This park lies in the centre of the town and offers respite from its hussle.  Parts have been replanted recently, most notably the rose garden.  The herb garden is in need of similar attention.  It provides lovely space of quiet and colour
Definitely nothing to go out of your way to see. But if you do go, don't miss the museum, it's worth a visit.
Lovely way to relax after traveling to town.  Ee spent about an hour walking through the gardens and chatting to many people
The park was , small filled with green areas and photographable spots. It is a very quick tour send nice place for a memorable journey

The park charges and entrance fee and that is absolutely ok however once you are inside it‚Äôs not amazing.  I guess I‚Äôm England we are spoilt with parks and so it didn‚Äôt give me a wow factor but it was a pleasant stroll to get to our restaurant across the town
This is a beautiful garden to visit. It costs only a nominal amount to go in and is a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

Green place with some flowers not special ones.the trees are so talk and beautiful.full of local people and at the bridge end of the park a very bad smelling pond.calm and relaxing place . I saw 3 teenage boy who were bothering 2 teenage girls and it was so sad to see such this acts on public . Walking is enjoyable at the park and it takes about 45 min to visit all the park.

I guess because of this dry season and apparently from info from our Tuk guy, this drought having come after 15years the area was rather lifeless and dry. Also many areas in the park were under reconstruction.

This park was close to out accommodation so we had some free time and thought we‚Äôd take a look - 300LKR for foreigners. It looks as though there are works going on which is well overdue by the look of things. They should also look at the creek flowing through the park as it does not look or smell good. That being said it has some very good looking displays to look at.

Centrally located, this garden is very well utilized by visitors and local folk. An excellent selection of flora and fauna can be seen and appreciated in this park. Garden beds and walking tracks are well maintained. An excellent variety and colorfully flowers can be enjoyed in this park

Us ‚Äòforeign adults‚Äô are charged 300 rupees each to enter the park, which is a bit steep in context with other Sri Lankan sites, however, hopefully the money goes towards maintaining the park. We strolled around most of the 26 acre site and enjoyed the birds and flowers. Best of all was chatting to the gardener and school children on a day trip who were keen to practice their English on us.

There was a small entrance fee to this park, 300 Rs. It was planting season so there were some ongoing maintenance works but otherwise it was a neat little place to stroll and relax. We happened to visit when bus loads of school children were there for a field trip. They and their teachers were extremely friendly so we ended up spending our time interacting and playing with them.

My wife and I visited here during our recent Birdwatching Tour of Sri Lanka. This park as well as being beautiful is also International renowned as a must visit Birding location. The park is well laid out with easy to follow paths. Our timing wasn‚Äôt perfect as many of the flowers had gone over. However, it was easy to imagine how impressive it would look in its prime. Several of the beds were already being replanted. Around the perimeter of the park there is a very smelly river, this was a magnet for many of the birds including some really sought after species - Kashmir Flycatcher, Pied Thrush, Forest Wagtail, Dusky Warbler and Sri Lanka Bush Warbler. We were so impressed we‚Äôre planning a second visit during our stay in Nuwara Eliya. Highly Recommended

The overall location is worth a visit. Very interesting English style buildings throughout the town and lots of interesting things to do and see. Restaurants and cafes too. There is a lovely park and an extensive lake, boat hire available.

Victoria Park is a public park located in Nuwara Eliya, next to the Nuwara Eliya Post Office. The park was formally named in 1897 to commemorate Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee.The park was established with the planting of its first tree, an Oak, by a visiting German Princess. The Nanu Oya River runs through the park, creating a number of small lakes. A number of rare bird species can be found in the park. At the far end of the park is a small children's playground and miniature rideable railway.(Wikepedia). If you are a nature lover, then this is an ideal place to relax with your loved ones. The beautiful flowers, the huge trees that gives its green, and the walkways, Now at presented its upgraded with paved roads, and there is an entrance fees, when we were kids we used to cross the park after school, and play around the grasslands. For the years things have changed, the main entrance was in front of the Post Office, later changed it to the other end of the park. Now they are preparing it for the April Season for the flowers to bloom for the guests to experience the different varieties of flowers. If you are in Nuwara Eliya just pop in you will witness what I have said and will come to know more about Victoria Park. Nizam - Little England Holidays
Take a stroll in this park and appreciate the botany. Vegetation is aged and lush. An expanse park and a nice place for a picnic.

The park is okay and pretty in parts. However, if they are going to charge for it the park needs to be maintained. There was loads of litter in the river and all around the park. You are better off paying for a cup of tea in the Grand Hotel and wandering around their gardens, which are absolutely beautiful.
A good place to have a extra time to spend in the town so have fun with the flowers and the bird watching inside the parking

I visited this park along with the rest of our bird watching group on one afternoon after doing Horton Plains Natl. Park that morning.  We stopped for a few hours primarily to find a few unusual birds that were tough to locate anywhere else.  This park was very busy (people everywhere), but we managed to find our own space for the most part away from the crowds.  Lots of flowers and for the most part good landscaping - just ignore some of the waterways as they are full of trash (and rats running around).  This could be a top notch little park if it was cleaned up a bit; just too much garbage laying around.

The park is very close to the Grand Hotel so you can easily combine visiting both. It is a small park which seemed to be very popular with Sri Lankan‚Äôs. It is well maintained but can‚Äôt be compared to the gardens in Kandy.
Very good garden on the top of the Mountain with chilled whether good activity place with ample plain surface

Visiting Victoria Park off season, when the flowers aren't in bloom, might seem to be pointless - but its not if you're into ornithology. The park boasts a selection of migrant birds and a few endemic ones that make a 6:30am visit worth while. Don't forget a long lens for some excellent captures.

I asked for my money back, they can‚Äôt charge for this park, is very Dirty, there is no workers there, no flowers, no plants... I know is not the season but they sont take care of this park. So they should not charge. Or should say before how is the reality of this disgusting park. They are very smart to take money from tourist, but I asked for my money back I didn‚Äôt find my money in the been. I think when you pay to see something you expect to SEE SOMETHING. Go to the Grand Hotel Garden, is free, beautiful, and clean.

Maybe it was the time of year we were there ( February) however Victoria Gardens was very disappointing! I would not pay to see gardens like this in February. Not too pleased at having to pay a lot more than the locals for entry! Surely the entrance price should be the same for everyone!

I didn‚Äôt come in the right season to see the flowers in bloom but if you‚Äôre looking for a quiet place that could be in England, this is the place. There‚Äôs a small museum with photos from the 1940s which show how different life was under English rule. There‚Äôs also a cafe with Italian coffee and Sri Lankan food at the north end of the park

We decided to spend an hour wandering in the park and at first sight it looked very attractive . However, I don't think much of the 300 rupee entrance fee is spent on litter collection, as the place is filthy.
We had an amasing day at the park. One of gartners guider us through the park , free of charge, to lots of interesting things about each plant. Lot to see and very beautyful
Bit early as planting just starting. Would imagine beautiful in the Spring . Felt sorry for ladies raking the grass. Bet on only few rupees.

Nothing that special to see. Looks like in history place has had nice fountains and bonds but now it's bit sad. Water/bonds is full of plastic trash.

The park is quite large and a peaceful enclave away from the bustle of the town, even though it's a very short walk from the bus station. The biggest issue is litter. There is a SLR300 charge for foreigners - it wouldn't take much to employ some litter pickers from this.
Nice gardens give a break from city life.  Big enough to walk and explore. 300 rupees entrance fee for foreign visitors

As usual a small foreign tourist entrance fee but not expensive , Lots of flowers and a Japanese Garden . Really it‚Äôs best because it‚Äôs very noisy once you exit the park to the shops and bus station.

At the gate after buying entry tickets you are guided towards the museum, big sign Silence, black and white photos the latest 1940. The park no flowers at this time of year, scruffy with big signs saying No Playing in the Park, and Behave with decorum. Enjoy at your peril!

This is a modest sized park with a lot of history. It`s  busy, well used ,safe for all. the audience is mainly the young kids plus 25-40`s.  No loud music,has a cafe and little areas with attractions that make a stroll worthwhile. You could do it all in no more than 30 minutes
Nice to stretch the legs. Have a look at the post office slightly down the road in Swiss? Architecture. I would not go out of my way just for the park but it is nice if you are passing by. through.
Not a great park, it is littered around the water way, what a shame! Nothing is flowering in January, however some of the trees are impressive.

It is just an ordinary park but a tourist attraction of this area. Good for families but not a park for full day activity. There is a children play area inside as well but on rainy day it is very messy.

This is probably a nice park in season, but in January it has little to offer except green lawns populated by pick-nicking groups and--unfortunately--feral dogs. The park was mostly clean, and there are three types of bins set up to encourage recycling.  No signs in English on those, so you will have to open them up to gauge what is appropriate.  However, there are some signs in English: one of them admonishing us to "Behave Decently."  I did my best. It is only Rs. 300 to get in.
Lovely park to spend an hour or two. Everything is very well maintained and the flowers are beautiful. I walked around for about an hour, then sat and read a book. Very ‚ÄúBritish‚Äù feel to it.
Victoria Park is quite large and beautifully green.  Well worth a stroll around, especially the herb garden.
Its only 300 rupees each but nothing was in flower etc so not worth a visit in my view. Other times of year may be better of course.
This is nice and in the middle of town - but it‚Äôs very small and lots of litter which really makes it unpleasant in parts - expensive for what it is
It's an ordinary garden, nothing great about it. We just walked around and we're out in less than an hour. Don't spend money and time on this location.

The park is dated and lacks safety aspects to ensure children do not hurt themselves. Nothing great to see or write about. We only went because we had spare time whilst waiting for our car. Very mediocre.

Went in Jan and no beautiful flowers and roses visible. Park was clean except for the stream that runs through the park which was smelly and had garbage. Should be way different in the April season. The play area was good for kids, the train was cool and may of the equipment. But the bouncy castle was dirty and the Ferris wheel looked dangerous. The grass was over grown and the ride areas were quite muddy. Entry ticket was cheap and nice place to watch the world pass by.

Having paid the entry fee we were disappointed with the state of the gardens.  Maintenance seemed to be lacking in many places and the children's play area didn't offer much more than 10mins worth of distraction for our two.  The miniature train is cute, but it didn't entice our kids to wait in line.
Not much to see in January in the gardens. The little stream was full of rubbish and the lawns needed mowing. OK for a quick visit on a nice day.

The Park is clearly a honeypot for local people as well as visitors. We enjoyed our walks here. The Park is immaculately maintained, or at least those parts in general view. We also followed the stream and walked through woodland and here there is rubbish galore. We were seeking birds and that was successful.
Well maintained, clean, calm. A good break from the more energetic surroundings and a nice path through the city. A small shop in the middle serve tea etc. Entry fee LKR 300.

Foreigners are charged 300 rupees to visit and that is fine if the park was kept in good condition. In December it all looks a bit 'tatty' - a park gardener was happy to tell us how lovely it looks in April. So for now, just a place to stroll for 20 minutes!

Definitely a must see in Nuwara Eliya, but please be mindful that this is a very small park.  One could finish walking around in 30 minutes or less.  We took our time and just enjoy walking inside of the park.

This is a lovely open space in the middle of the town. We visited for the birdlife that can be seen there. Early morning is the best time before there is too much disturbance from human visitors. As well as the obvious egrets in the open areas there are different birds all along the stream and vegetation on the opposite side of the park. This is a site for wintering Pied Thrush At the time of one of our visits see saw two wedding parties having photographs taken. There are small kiosks for buying drinks and snacks. Odd quirk - mens and womens toilets are at opposite sides of the park.
If you visit Nuwaraeliya  the one place that you should not miss is Victoria Park. It's nicely maintain lot of various kinds of flowers. Good walk around the park refreshing your mind
One of the oldest Gardens in Sri-Lanka, still well maintained, has the old world charm. Good to relax on a sunny day.

Nice relaxing park - crazily English except the fact that you have to pay to get in! Well maintained and very clean. Well policed and very safe. Ok children's area which gave our kids some space to run around. Ok for a spare relaxing afternoon if you have one.
Loved the place and the endless array of trees and flowers.  Nice place for a stroll with a loved one. Quiet and serene. Be sure to bring a sweater

By chance we bumped into the head gardener who gave us a very good tour. I suspect he does this for a few tourists and we did give him a tip.  We left with a much better knowledge of plants in Sri lanka. At 300 LKA to enter its only a couple of UK ¬£ so we did not begrudge that . And compared with the nearby town bustle and fumes its a place of peace and quiet. It was also close to our hotel so a pleasant walk.

Not being used to having to pay to visit a public park I guess one feels a little hard done by when all our parks are free to all. At 300 LKR I guess it is not a lot but the standard then one would expect to be higher. A asmall variety of colour was on display. Apart from the odd tree label none of the flower beds gave any description. Obviously popular to the locals on a Sunday with a children's area also. Really only an average garden good for a stroll.
Nice city garden in the middle of city. Have children play area. Good for walk for elders. I feel entry tickets should not be there at morning times for elder tourist who go there for morning walks.

We wanted to visit the childrens park. Unfortunately only accessible through the park, meaning that we had to buy a 300 rps ticket. Park is pretty and well kept, but we thought the entrance fee was a bit steep. Toilets are filthy. Childrens park was fun to while away an hour with two under 5's. Attractions have got some sharp edges and are generally quite run down. There is a rather dodgy ferris wheel - we went for a ride but it was spinning at great speed and afterwards this no longer felt like such a good idea.

The Victoria Park is much like a botanical garden with varied trees and flowering plants. It also has sprawling green lawns and a play area for kids. The entry fee is LKR 300 and is open from 7am to 7pm on all days.  The park was christened in 1897 to commemorate Queen Victoria's Diamond Jubilee.
It's just fine, not as good as the Botanical Garden in Kandy but great if you want to walk around and see Srilankan families relaxing.
dont go on weekends, it was very near to our hotel. enjoyed a quiet long walk here on a mid week day. it was comparetively cheaper than other tourist attracrions for foriegners

Head gardener gave us a special tour through "his" park. He was very knowledgeable having studied 2 years in Kandy, owning many books of German botanical gardens and working already 16 years in this park. Many flowers and trees were presented by their German name. Although I have to agree with another feedback that there is waste laying around, the excellent tour outweighed this fact by far!
When we visited the were school children in groups in the park,reminded the park in kandy we visited 2days before,

The park was quite nice with some enjoyable spots, but it was not exceptional so the entrance fee (only for foreign) is not justified. In some places there are some stray dogs that tried to attack people

This is a very large park, very well maintened grassland and trees. Together with other neighboring public parks and lake makes this Nuwara Eliza looks like a very nice European or a new world town. A good place to relax or take your kids to ride on a pony.

The pack is really nice (except for requiring to pay entrance fee!) - there's a kids corner, where you can find the unique attraction. Diesel-engine powered faris wheel! You may even see the staff climbing up to the top and hanging on the cart to get it spinning. It's quite surreal to see... :)
Not quite sure why you have to pay to walk around a park but there you go - pleasant enough 30 - 45mins unless you have kids maybe longer.
The best part is the children park if you have kids,  entrance fees 300 repuee. Recommended for maximum 1 hour
In the middle of the city you'll find this calm park, wide area contains many species of trees and flowers and they have a special corner for the birds
Lovely park to wander around or relax in. A small fee for foreign guests of 300 rupees. Worth a visit.

Its a good place to be with kids families friends or with your partner. Either you want to relax on the grassy ground and benches or walk in between huge flower beds. Huge  botanical variation of flowers and plants. Decorated with water fountains and nice little paths. Recommend for families and this is one of the must see locations in Nuwara Eliya..

We strolled through the park after having been cooped up in our room due to cxld program and rain. A nice park. Not big, not fancy, but clean. For us it was a breath of fresh air (in both meanings) as Nurawa Eliya was such a disappointment for us.

Victoria park is quite nice and well kept - you have to pay to enter but it's a nice activity as Nuwara Eliya offers few things to do. The park is quite big and has a lot of places to sit. There is a play area for children.

The queen victroia park is located by the nuwara eliya city. victroria park is a place to relax and enjoy the natural sight and clean mountain air.this place is famous for bird watching and there are large verities of plants and trees available. victoria park come alive with the flowers specially around march to may, and august and September. we will come victoria park again.
We enjoyed visiting the park. We saw few birds amidst of windy weather. Flowers are blossoming. I could show some tourists  Sri Lanka National flower and some endemic birds of Sri Lanka.
Nice and clean park in the middle of the city. Nice to walk with the kids. Funny children play park (try the big wheel).

Lovely, well manicured garden with huge variety of flowers all of which were in bloom in August. Very relaxed environment and pleasant place to take a walk. Seems popular with tourists and locals alike.

Been this wonderful place just after my wedding as a honeymoon location. It's a superb environment with very fresh air in the central province of Sri Lanka. Highly recommended for couples who wish to spend time leisurely in a clean environment in Sri Lanka. Love this place
All the foreigners have to pay the entrance fee and it is not worth the entrance fee spent and you can spend driving around the hills for this time.

Victoria park is a fairly typical Victorian style park, only in Sri Lanka. The gardens are not particularly well maintained and there are signs that say you cannot play in the park. With an entry fee that is a little on the hefty side, I felt it was not good value.
The park ia beautifully landscaped. There is a rose garden but it wasnt in bloom. The trees and smalls ponds are lovely. There is a good childrens play area as well with all kinds of swings.
Not a must visit. If you have spare days 8n Nuwara Eliya have a visit in the cold evening rather than morning.
Perhaps the time of the year isn't right as we didn't see many flowers blooming. Small garden for evening walks. Completed it less then an hour.
This is some wonderful green experience. It has Lilly garden very well maintained. You can complete the park within 2 hours very easily by walking.
Perfect place for a walk if you stay in Nuwara eliya town. Nice atmosphere for a relax time. There are few food spots where you can buy snacks and all fruits. Great place to kids
This is the one of attractive garden in Nuwara Eliya. Nice place to walk and lots or beautiful flowers. If you go to Nuwara Eliya you should reserve your time to visit this beautiful garden.
Finding beautiful gardens with lovely flowers and various areas to just unwind and relax is just wonderful. There's a kiddies area as well (thank goodness).

We visited one morning and spent a couple of hours wandering about looking at the flowers.  The thing which made thus such a brilliant experience was only that the Gardener Tony started chatting to us and basically gave us a free guided tour telling us about each flower.  I'm not that into flowers personally but his enthusiasm was so infectious that you couldn't help but enjoy it!
It is a normal park where you can go for a walk and spend some time. Not a must go place but if you have leisure time then you can go for a walk.

This is a beautiful park and located in the centre of the city. It was wonderful, walking through the gardens among the colourful flowers and pin trees, and reviving childhood memories. Good to see that security is vigilant and misbehaviour monitored closely, but litterers should be equally closely monitored. Rather amusing to see signs that exhorted couples to 'behave decently' There was some rubbish near the natural stream near the entrance, which rather spoiled the pristine beauty of the park. The rose garden was not as verdant as I remembered, though, which was rather sad, but given the vast expanse that has to be maintained, this was forgivable. I don't agree with people who don't want to pay to enter. This is a poor country and money is needed for maintaining attractions such as these. The fact that it is for the entire family means that couples really should 'behave decently' - the verdant landscapes of Nuwara Eliya give them much more scope for romance.

This is pretty ancient part with lush green grass and variety of flowers. I am sure you gonna like it. The park also have a connectivity to children park with lots of swings options for kids. Park has entrance fees of 300 LKR per person. But a must go place.

Park entry is 300 roepies for a foreigner, 40 for a local. For Sri Lanka standards, that is pretty high. So I was very dissapointed to see all the plastic rubbish lying in the park in the ditches, all the grass groing out of the pavement, and some buildings needing a make over 10 years ago already....

Before we arrived here we think this park to be nice place to visit. But when we entered the park it was nice but as a couple we can't sitting,hanging hands together or a doing a funny things.. because one of the security lady coming and scolding us "don't doing this and this,this is a children's park" so after this stuff we are went out the park. I really hate this place and I'm not recommended this place to anyone.

As a keen horticulturalist we took a walk through the park and met the head gardener . Never caught his name , but a great guy with a passion for plants. We spent an hour together walking around sharing our knowledge , and he gave us a personal tour of the parks special plants . Great that you can go half way around the world and meet someone with a very similar passion and interest.

I was deeply shocked to be asked for 300 rupees to enter this park. Whether this is the official foreigner rate or a scam I don't know. In England parks are free. I have no objection, as an overseas visitor, to making a reasonable contribution to Sri Lankan parks such as this but excessive demands will result in NO revenue. I just walked away. If an individual was trying to make a dishonest charge, he should be sacked. If not the authorities need to review their charges. It would be sensible if charges were advertised at the entrance. A tax rate of 0% or 100% will yield nothing. An excessive park charge will yield nothing. I love Sri Lanka and especially the people but beware of greed. Foreigners are not silly and news of bad experiences travels fast.

It is the onle place which will be guarnteed to hold a spot a soft place in our hearts! The romantic walks before tying the knot and later the visit with a kid and then with two! A place to make memories forever. Has an adequately well maintained Children park with makeshift (and safe) ferry's wheel, a small motored train with its own track and passenger carriages - Adults too can use it!! ;)
the location is perfect in the down town. it's very well planned landscape and beautiful. whithin 1 hour can do that
Nice Park,  we'll maintained,  good trees and greenery nice place to CHILL and relax good place to take pics
not a bigger park like royal botanical garden or hakgala park but still an eco friendly, urban park. its like a park in England.
The park is good for a family visit and children can play in the play area. It's a bit crowded, but still you can enjoy a relaxed walk or sit and enjoy the surrounding.
Good to see well maintained. Nice flowers and trees. A bit small but there is an old small bridge where can catch good picture.

A  beautiful garden in Nuwara Eliya. There is a small entry fee. Good for a nice evening stroll. The flowers are beautiful though they are also seen in other parts of the Indian subcontinent. A few beautioful birds and monkeys also can be seen.

This is a really beautiful park and has many attractive species of flora however it is badly maintained. The visitors seem to be thrashing the place too much which is a really sad site to see and simply ruins the whole landscape.
This place has a wide variety of plants.Has beautiful scenery.We enjoyed our visit thoroughly.A must visit if you are in Nuwara Eliya.
The call it botanical garden but actually it's not a real botanical, you'll find some kind of plants there but not endemic ones,anyway a calm and beautiful park for morning or afternoon walk.
Nice park- as non Sri Lankan you pay 300 rupees to get in. It's not as big as we thought and you could do this park in 15-30 mins. Lovely flowers. Some stray dogs around but not an issue.
Victoria park is garden with full of flowers. Very close to Nuwara-Eliya city area. Able ti cover within 1hr.
Really a nice place with nice climate and wonderful flowers, we all enjoyed with different plants and flowers. The garbage segregation bins were amazing...
Very well taken care of and nice for a short stroll in the sun....you might get lucky and bump into one of the gardeners who will happily tell you more about the flowers, even in other languages!

The park was well maitained with a lot of  people working for the great tourist season,which would start for the weekend,saturday 1/4.We went there for a couple of hours and realised that many of the flowers are common potted plants in Sweden.
There are a different varieties of flowers and plants. There is a playground for children. Nice place to sit and read and relax.

An easy if not that inspiring option if you're looking for something to do in Nuwara Eliya, especially with young children. There is an entrance fee for foreigners of a few pounds. It's a pleasant place to take some short eats for a picnic but we preferred Gregory Lake as a child-friendly destination.
It was nice to visit this park as the town was very busy. It is a well kept space for a pleasant walk.
The flowers and in the mood in the place is completely stunning, recommend this place a lot; especially to people who love flowers.
In April it is full of flowers and peoples. So nice to see. There are many things to ses and to take potos.if you visit nuwaraelliya Don't forget to visit
This park is well maintained and one feels really refreshed walking around . It is a good quiet place to spend the evening.

There was a festival on at the time, so not sure if it happens every week, but it was great fun. We saw a man with a huge Python AND 3 Cobras!! Great experience with these amazing animals. There's a fun kids park with swings, monkey bars etc., and large manicured lawn areas for relaxing. Good for few hours to let kids run around.
Not the best park in Sri Lanka and probably best to avoid on national holidays if you're looking for serenity but it helps in escaping the heat.

Really enjoyed these gardens, financially much cheaper than Hakgala.  Good to visit early in the morning when the dew is still on the flowers.  Bigger than I thought at first, it stretches for quite a way.  Happily spent a couple of hours here, along with a few tourists, locals and the odd group of school children.  Options to purchase food and drinks also available.  A nice spot.
April could be the nicest season to visit as almost all the flowers were blossoming. Nicely maintained but some shops in the middle and temporary huts make the entire thing look messy.
Good place to visit and enjoy the greenery. Hakgala Botanic Gardens are much better to visit and this place can be as a second option.
No ticket for Sri Lankan's .these days they are renovating inside the park so some places are closed due to that reason

A lovely park, wonderful green, with flowers, birds and trees, really pleasant hideout for families. We also visited the small,  informative museum explaining the history of Nuwara Eliya and the surrounding areas, particularly exciting to learn more about how the railways were built and the plantations. Recommended!
nice place to relax in cold atmosphere flowers are beautiful romantic and cold environment  optionally can have Pony ride for kids
Beautifully kept gardens, we spent about an hour here just meandering around, I was taken aback by the size and number of the Bamboo and also some of the huge old trees.
We went there with three kids. Nice and calm place. There is a small park for younger kids to play in.
Beautiful green park that all enjoys. Groups, kids, all. Also a golf course nearby. A nice stroll, a nice place.

Classic Victorian-era Botanic Garden, with some wonderful notices " All clergys get free entry"  "Behave decently"; also a great birding spot, with Indian Pitta, Pied Thrush and Kashmir Flycatcher on our short late afternoon visit.

The park in the middle of the city just next to the main bus station. Nicely kept but too much noise from the roads around the park. Small green house about 10 meter square with nothing worthy to see. They have a small play ground for children with a horse ride. Nice stroll for people who like to walk away from the busy streets with good paved walking path. Good roses display and they have some benches for resting or reading. The charge to enter is 300 rupes for tourist and much less for locals.
Almost feels like bring in London, but not quite. Pretty gardens and make for a relaxing stroll but the hills and tea plantations outweigh it in beauty.
Excellent green spot in the heart of Nuwara Eliya.  Pleasant place for a stroll, picnic, or for kids to play.

We visited the park twice during this years stay in Nuwara Eliya. It being February the whole place was in its Landscape maintenance phase, and since we had frost in the mornings, many of the new plantings were under protective covers, but it was still well worth the entrance fee.
Very nice park in the middle of Nuwara Elyia. Very nice to see the local people and the school children. Everybody was talking to us, we enjoyed it.
We visited Victoria park for the children park purpose only so my kid can play... everywhere is filled with mud and water... there is nothing to do except talking pictures...

A well maintained, compact, attractive Park.  It would have been 3 steals but for the helpfulness of the staff. My wife wanted to use the lavatory, but the signs all pointed to a Sri Lankan facility which she declined to use. One of the staff insisted on escorting her to an unmarked European wash room elsewhere in the park ,which he checked out before he let her use it.

Visited this park just before a rainy shower - beautiful variety of shrubs, flowers and trees, well maintained and thoughtfully designed. Heavy rainfall led to us taking shelter in the park's central shelter where we found many families enjoying their day out; we ended up making lots of new friends, young and old. There is a reasonably priced restaurant at the entrance with an adequate, if very limited menu, as well as a cafe inside the park serving drinks and snacks. Staff are friendly and helpful and the park was a welcome change from the frantic pace of the surrounding area. Stray dogs abound but pose no problem as they peacefully coexist with park goers and simply sit watching the world go by - I recommend you do the same in this beautiful park.

This park is situated right in the middle of the town. We were spending a little time here it was a nice place to walk around. This can be crowded on weekends and holidays. If you want to have a quick look of flowers this si a better place. If you with your partner it is a nice place to roam around.

Any place should be evaluated based on what it offers, not for what we hope to find there. Victoria Park was not meant to be a tourist attraction. It's a local public park with some interesting history. We visited in February and it seemed some of the beauty had faded away in the winter months and some planting and gardening works were going on. I bet it looks much more beautiful in Spring and Summer. We still found it to be a lovely park for a pleasant stroll while also exploring some of its historic areas and trees. The playground had lots of fun rides and our daughter enjoyed them a lot. Like most places we visited in Sri Lanka, mornings and evenings seem to be the best times to visit the park. Ticket prices are very reasonable and should be appreciated because the money goes into the maintenance and upkeep of the park. I recommend it for tourists who appreciate leisurely walks in relaxing settings.

This is not terribly exciting but a pleasant place to spend an hour or 2. Several interesting birds and one of the gardeners took us under his wing, so to speak and showed us birds we would not have seen by ourselves.
Just a park like any other Victoria park in the world apart that it is paying... old playarea, tacky train ride...

The road from Kandy to Nuwara is a must see in Sri Lanka. The nature is remarkable. Then you get in Nuwara and oops, well, this is not Sri Lanka. This is a colonial British style, but still the town with its green scenery and Victoria park is a pleasure for the eyes. The park itself is not something you cannot miss (it just look like a park) but the whole Nuwara is something different to feel in Sri Lanka.

The garden supervisor took us around the gardens and showed us lots of plants, extremely knowledgeable and friendly. They had lost a lot of plants to frost the week before and I believe these gardens are at their best in the spring.
A small park in the centre of the city, with a very steep entrance fee for foreigners (as elsewhere, locals get almost for free). Not worth the money or the time wasted.

Park looks ...like a park, moreover surrounded by all sort of vehicles' emissions, that look black and heavy while they are going right on your face and straight to your lungs. Moreover you must pay more than 7 times what locals pay. This place shouldn't be on the list of the things to do in Nuwara Eliya. And if you are a traveller, don't even stop in Nuwara Eliya. Higher prices for lower offer.
...like this are uncommon in South Asia but they are an integral part of this very pleasant town. Well worth a stroll after the hectic tours in Kandy.
Absolutely gorgeous greens with plenty of flora and fauna. Loved walking around in the park. Children loved playing in the grassy fields.

A nice garden decently maintained and relaxing to go through. Being less than 10 min walking distance from all the main hotels and guest houses, this park is very conveniently and centrally located. Could do with a bit more maintanence work, but can manage the way it is. a few endemic plants which are not found beyond this region is an added bonus. The childrens park needs to be revamped and better maintained. But still a lovely evening.

The park is nice, but it needs many improvements. The tiny river smells like bathroom waste, pushing a baby stroller was a bit tricky on the broken grounds at some places, etc. In short, it needs more care.

Neatly kept park for peaceful enjoyment. The flowers weren't out as it was the wrong season but the park is well maintained and a pleasant area for a rest. The children's area looks like a lot of fun incorporating a Ferris wheel and a little train. The museum is very interesting with many photos of years gone by.  Well worth a visit.

We visited the park with our two children, aged 9 & 10. You have to buy tickets to enter the park. There seems to be a scam going at the ticket office, where the posted price does not match the ticket price. The price for foreign adults is R300 each, but the children's admission price is not indicated. We gave R1200 and got four tickets and no change. Off we went to visit the park, however a short while later, on examining the tickets, we noticed that the children are charged at half price, i.e. R150! We went back to the ticket office to inquire and immediately the R300 change appeared, as if by magic... As for the park, it's quite pleasant but definitely overrated.
All this park needs is some TLC and a work crew to clean it. Since foreigners pay for entry that does not seem too difficult.
You can spend your whole day roaming around this beautiful park. For locals it's s prime location for pre wedding shoots. Entry fee is Srilanka Rs 50 for residents and Rs 200 for foreigners.

This lovely park is totally an English Victorian-era creation.  It's been looked after though, so despite its age it still does what it was designed for - providing a pleasant walk amongst flowers and trees.

As we were showing interest in the plants we were approached by the Superintendent who gave us a personal tour for three quarters of an hour, showing us things we never would have spotted for ourselves. An enthusiast for the Royal Horticultural Society he was delighted to share his expertise.

Not a big park, but it is very nice to walk around and relax while you read a book/the newspaper. Every is 300 rupees for an adult (foreigner) which includes every to a small museum at the entrance gates showing historic photos of the town and tea plantations.

A nice piece of English gardening with local plants. You have to pay and indeed a lot more than the locals. I prefer to see that as a little contribution to the maintenance of the park. After all, it's only 300 RS (20 SEK/about 2‚Ç¨).
Well maintained and pretty park to walk around. Also has security guards. Lovely in the sunshine. Foreigners cost is 300 lkr to enter. Nice place to take children.

The Park is beautiful, and well organized. Perfect for picnics, walking or even if you just wanna chill on the grass. It has so many different type of planets and tree and even a small Japanese Garden inside There are spots for bird watching too. There is an entr√©e fee for the Park but its for full day
Nice park, but there is really not that much to see. You can come there for a walk, make some people watching but the place is not special.

As usual foreigners pay about ten times as much as locals to see this attraction. The park is well laid out but needs time and money spent on it. We also visited at a time of year whe the roses had been pruned and most flower beds cleared and recently re-planted so there was little colour to be seen.
Lovely coffee lovely staff and service. Food looked good too. Delightful little place to stop and chill out.
It was a normal park with swings yet the ticket was 300lkr for saarc countries. A park should be free

It was a Festival Day in Nuwara Eliya and the park was full of local families out in the sunshine enjoying themselves. We were lucky to get chatting with the head gardener who had a wealth of knowledge of all the trees and flowers in the park. He showed us many beautiful smelling flowers. He explained that now is the season for them to be planting and tending new seedlings. Many were covered to protect from frost. He said in another couple of months the park will be full of flowers and look very pretty. It was lovely to walk around anyway. There is a very large playground for younger children.
Park is good and maintained well enough but overly priced entry fees is put off... Never going to be back there

If you want to see a small well (see the picture) that is moved by power generator and use some artificial playground facilities you need to visit this park. The entrance fee is 300 LKR per person (tickets only for adults) and the ride on the well is additional 100 LKR per persons

The city is a base for visits to Horton Plains National Park. This is a key wildlife area of open grassy woodland. Species found here include the leopard, sambar, and the endemic purple-faced langur. Endemic highland birds include the dull-blue flycatcher, Sri Lanka white-eye, and yellow-eared bulbul. The plains have a well-visited tourist attraction at World's End ‚Äî a sheer precipice with a 1050 m drop. The return walk passes the scenic Baker's Falls. Early morning visits are best, both to see the wildlife and to view World's End before mists close in during the later part of the morning. One of the distinctive features of Nuwara Eliya's countryside is the widespread growing of vegetables, fruit and flowers usually associated with temperate Europe. This "Little England" is covered with terraces growing potatoes, carrots, leeks, and roses, interspersed with tea bushes on the steeper slopes. The slow-growing tea bushes of this highland region produce some of the world's finest orange pekoe tea. Several tea factories around Nuwara Eliya offer guided tours and the opportunity to sample or purchase their products.
